Legal_Issue: Entitlement to mandamus; Charter rights violation
Evidence_Assessment: Delays due to policy changes; no binding representations
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show unreasonable delay and entitlement to relief
Credibility_Factor: No evidence of bad faith or arbitrary conduct by Minister
Legal_Rule: Mandamus requires unreasonable delay, no justification, and equity; Charter s.7 and s.15 not applicable to non-citizens outside Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable delay; alleged violation of Charter rights and rule of law
Outcome_on_Merits: No entitlement to mandamus or Charter relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Changes in processing priorities and quotas
Legal_Framework: IRPA discretion; principles of administrative law; Charter applicability
Defendant_Response: Delays due to legitimate policy adjustments; no Charter obligations
Remedy_Requested: Order of mandamus; declaration of Charter violation

Legal_Issue: Whether the Applicants qualify for Canadian citizenship under the Citizenship Act and whether the Officer's decision violated their Charter rights
Governing_Law: Citizenship Act (sections 3(1)(b), 3(3)(a), 3(4)), Charter of Rights and Freedoms (section 15)
Evidence_Assessment: Father's retroactive Canadian citizenship, Applicants' birth abroad
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicants to demonstrate entitlement to citizenship and violation of Charter rights
Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – decision based on statutory interpretation
Legal_Rule: Citizenship by descent limited to first generation born abroad; Section 15 Charter protection requires standing and membership in a protected group
Grounds_for_Claim: Charter rights violation (equality rights under s. 15), statutory misinterpretation
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer's decision upheld as reasonable; Applicants do not qualify for citizenship
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants' father's retroactive citizenship, place of birth of Applicants, generational limit under Citizenship Act
Legal_Framework: Citizenship Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, principles of statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: Officer applied section 3(3)(a) correctly; Applicants lack standing for Charter challenge
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of citizenship restoration, legal status records
Remedy_Requested: Grant of Canadian citizenship, declaration that decision violated Charter
Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CBSA's preliminary assessment of inadmissibility on security grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CBSA failed to assess Galloway's intent behind aid delivery
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Humanitarian nature of aid, lack of intent to support terrorism
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged support for Hamas through humanitarian aid
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of analysis of donor's purpose or intent
Crimes.Application_Error: Overreach in interpreting facts and law without sufficient basis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Intent and actual use of humanitarian aid
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe, more than suspicion but less than balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delivery of aid to Gaza under Hamas control
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed due to absence of final reviewable decision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing material support to a terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged support to Hamas, a listed terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential enhancement of terrorist activities through material support
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: CBSA's determination of risk based on aid delivery

Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Voluntary delivery of humanitarian aid (cash and goods)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Acknowledged delivery of aid, denied terrorist intent
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No evidence of leadership or operational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence showed aid was humanitarian and not diverted to terrorism
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Absence of intent to further terrorist objectives
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentation of humanitarian purpose, public statements, aid distribution records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Galloway's intent assessed as humanitarian, not supportive of terrorism
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Transparency of aid mission, public nature of delivery
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Attempted exclusion from Canada, blocked speaking tour

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Allegation of membership in Hamas due to aid delivery
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: CBSA’s belief that Galloway may be complicit via support
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with a listed terrorist entity despite humanitarian intent
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Delivery of humanitarian aid through Hamas channels
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Acknowledged involvement in aid delivery only
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership or organizational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supporting evidence demonstrated purely humanitarian objectives
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: No evidence of intent to engage in terrorism or organizational membership
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Publicly documented aid mission, recipient use of supplies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible assertion of humanitarian purpose
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistent public statements, transparency of actions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of preliminary inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Prevention of entry into Canada for speaking tour

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Existence of public legal duty for mandamus
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Courts Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No evidence provided by applicant to support claim
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence regarding Charter violation or public duty
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request for Canadian government intervention in foreign criminal proceedings
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Foreign affairs fall under Crown prerogative
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to establish public legal duty
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Mandamus requirements: public duty, clear right, practical value

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, denied refugee status, deported
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with visa conditions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian courts lack jurisdiction over foreign criminal proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of deportation and conviction in China
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of Charter violation or duty to act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No credibility finding made; lack of legal basis
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Government response regarding trial in China
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No public legal duty exists post-deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit refusal and request for intervention
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Existence of public legal duty for mandamus following deportation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Courts Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPR
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No evidence submitted to support entitlement to relief
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Absence of proof of Charter breach or governmental duty
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request for Canadian government action regarding trial in China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Foreign national outside Canada; no Charter violation
Crimes.Application_Error: Misunderstanding of Crown's foreign affairs prerogative
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for issuing writ of mandamus
Crimes.Application_Factor: Conviction in China for contract fraud after deportation
Crimes.Authority: Immigration authorities and Department of Foreign Affairs

Governing_Law: Principle of mootness in judicial review
Application_Facts: Visa officer revoked immigrant visas; new visas were later issued
Claimant_Status: Applicants whose visas were revoked and reissued
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No live controversy due to reissuance of visas
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to challenge visa revocation
Standard_of_Review: De novo or correctness standard for legal questions
Decision_Rationale: Underlying controversy resolved by reissuance of visas; no adversarial context or useful purpose for declaratory relief

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; Board considered available evidence but found it insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false documents and implausible explanations
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Counterfeit entry stamp and suspicious passport issuance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision

Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to substantiate key aspects of the claim with evidence

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in travel and documentation history

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada using a false Japanese passport and lacked original identity documents.

Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister can confirm reassessments initially based on a repealed section of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Law: Sections 152(3), 152(8), 166, and s. 74(5) (repealed) of the Income Tax Act
Procedural_Stage: Objections, confirmation of reassessments, motion under Federal Court Rule 474
Evidence_Assessment: Initial reliance on repealed s. 74(5), correction by Minister using valid sections (ss. 3 and 9)
Burden_of_Proof: On defendant to show error was substantial and fundamental
Legal_Rule: Errors in assessment do not invalidate assessments unless they are substantial and fundamental; Minister may correct errors
Grounds_for_Claim: Initial reliance on a repealed statutory provision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of reassessment, applicable sections of the Income Tax Act, precedent (Belle-Isle)
Legal_Framework: Income Tax Act, Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: Argued that reliance on a repealed section invalidated the reassessment
Legal_Provision: ss. 152(3), 152(8), 166, 3, 9, and formerly s. 74(5) of the Income Tax Act
Authority: Minister of National Revenue, Federal Court

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Safe Third Country Agreement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant transited through Trinidad and the U.S. without claiming refugee protection
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national seeking refugee protection in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to seek protection in first safe country of arrival

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No justification provided for not claiming earlier

Crimes.Relief_Sought: Refugee protection and stay in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of RPD’s interpretation of eligibility criteria
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Delay and availability of protection elsewhere weaken claim of urgent fear

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether inconsistent testimony invalidated subjective fear claim

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed trauma affected memory, but explanation not accepted

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in refusing the temporary resident visa application
Evidence_Assessment: The officer dismissed the application based on perceived weak family ties and insufficient financial resources, despite substantial evidence provided by the applicants
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate intent to leave Canada and meet admissibility requirements
Credibility_Factor: Applicants provided evidence of financial stability and familial ties
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA and its regulations, a visa can be issued if the officer is satisfied that the foreign national will leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay and meets other requirements
Grounds_for_Claim: Errors in decision-making process, including failure to consider relevant evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: The Federal Court found the decision unreasonable due to inadequate reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial stability, familial ties in home country
Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained refusal based on weak ties and finances
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of financial status and family connections
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review and remitted the matter for redetermination by a different visa officer

Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation due to failure to depart after visa expiration
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a U.S. citizen who remained in Canada beyond the authorized period and has prior U.S. convictions
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with departure notice
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of adjudicator's decision on equivalency and stay of deportation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Canadian immigration authorities to enforce deportation

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay of deportation dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation based on irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to prove irreparable harm and favorable balance of convenience for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Arrest in U.S. due to own wrongdoing does not constitute irreparable harm; separation from fiancée insufficient for threshold

Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Colistro was constructively dismissed by the Bank
Evidence_Assessment: Adjudicator reviewed disciplinary actions, workplace incidents, and resignation circumstances; court found no evidence of bias or factual error sufficient to overturn decision
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator's decision upheld; constructive dismissal not established
Burden_of_Proof: On Mr. Colistro to prove constructive dismissal
Credibility_Factor: Adjudicator assessed credibility of Mr. Colistro's claims and employer's conduct
Legal_Rule: Constructive dismissal occurs when employer's actions force an employee to resign
Grounds_for_Claim: Disciplinary notices, workplace conflicts, alleged constructive dismissal
Key_Evidence_Considered: Disciplinary actions, workplace incidents, voluntary resignation
Legal_Framework: Federal employment law, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Bank maintained that Mr. Colistro resigned voluntarily and was not constructively dismissed
Remedy_Requested: Recognition of constructive dismissal, potential compensation
Outcome: Application dismissed, adjudicator's decision affirmed, costs awarded to respondent

Crime_Name: Administrative Dispute over Band Council Elections
Dispute_Type: Election dispute between competing band customs for council leadership
Legal_Issue: Which band custom governs the election of the Nekaneet band council: the Referendum Band Custom or the Second Band Custom?
Evidence_Assessment: Referendum Band Custom approved by 83% of participating voters (113 out of 136); minor irregularities did not affect outcome; Second Band Custom passed by show of hands without clear consensus
Decision_Outcome: Referendum Band Custom is valid and governs elections; Applicants recognized as rightful Chief and Councillors
Burden_of_Proof: On Applicants to demonstrate validity of Referendum Band Custom and lack of broad consensus for Second Band Custom
Credibility_Factor: High voter participation in referendum (113/136) and significant portion of eligible voters (267 total) supports legitimacy
Legal_Rule: Under the Indian Act, band customs must reflect a broad consensus among band members
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and correctness, as applicable to judicial review and writ of quo warranto
Grounds_for_Claim: Two conflicting elections held under different customs causing uncertainty over legitimate council
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of Applicants; Respondents' claim to office declared invalid
Key_Evidence_Considered: Referendum results (113-23), voter turnout, procedural irregularities, method of adoption of Second Band Custom
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Act allowing judicial review and issuance of writs of quo warranto
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but implied defense of validity of Second Band Custom adopted by show of hands
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (referendum results), oral procedure (show of hands), procedural records
Remedy_Requested: Declarations of rightful office holders and writ of quo warranto
Outcome: Court granted declarations; Applicants declared legitimate band council
Legal_Provision: Section 74 of the Indian Act (band elections), Federal Courts Act sections on judicial review and prerogative writs

Dispute_Type: Trademark Infringement and Opposition to Registration
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's trademarks are confusingly similar to the respondent's existing trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trademarks Opposition Board decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Substantial overlap in targeted consumer bases and product categories; significant recognition of Chinese characters among respondent’s clientele
Decision_Outcome: Appeals dismissed; registration of applicant's trademarks refused
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to prove lack of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Recognition of Chinese characters in the marketplace by relevant consumers
Legal_Rule: A trademark is confusing if its use would likely cause the public to infer that the goods or services come from the same source
Standard_of_Review: Likelihood of confusion under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on similarity of marks leading to potential consumer confusion
Outcome_on_Merits: Respondent succeeded; applicant's marks deemed too similar to established trademarks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Consumer base overlap, product category similarity, linguistic recognition (Chinese characters)
Defendant_Response: Opposed registration on grounds of likelihood of confusion
Evidence_Type: Market perception evidence, trademark usage data, consumer recognition studies
Outcome: Registration refused due to likelihood of confusion

Legal_Issue: Use of prosecution history to establish estoppel in patent claims
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from initial refusal; amendment considered
Evidence_Assessment: Prosecution statements deemed irrelevant to claim construction
Decision_Outcome: Paragraphs relying on prosecution history were struck out
Burden_of_Proof: On defendants to establish estoppel, but failed due to inadmissible basis
Legal_Rule: Scope of a patent is determined solely by its issued claims; prosecution history cannot create estoppel
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, based on established legal interpretation principles
Grounds_for_Claim: Plaintiffs sought to remove allegations of estoppel based on prosecution statements
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of plaintiffs; defense arguments based on prosecution history invalidated
Legal_Framework: Patent Act (Canada); judicial precedents on claim construction
Defendant_Response: Asserted estoppel based on plaintiff's prosecution conduct
Remedy_Requested: Striking out of paragraphs in the statement of defense
Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of Canadian Patent Act and common law on claim scope
Authority: Judge Strayer; precedent from Canadian courts on prosecution history estoppel

Crimes.Application_Facts: Nabiloo was sentenced to over two years for drug possession; appeal of conviction was pending.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal to IAD dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD lacked jurisdiction under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious criminality based on imposed sentence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: 'Punished' refers to the sentence imposed, not the outcome of a pending appeal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 64(2) IRPA bars appeal during criminal appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Imposed sentence of over two years considered sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD appeal dismissed; judicial review denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to establish eligibility for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 64(2) IRPA applies if sentence is at least two years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to IAD's lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA provisions on inadmissibility and appeals
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued punishment not final due to pending appeal

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction; Federal Court dismissed application
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug offenses with three-year sentence
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Sentence of three years triggers s. 64(2) IRPA bar

Dispute_Type: Trademark opposition and potential consumer confusion
Legal_Issue: Whether the Trade-marks Opposition Board erred in allowing Orange's trademark registration despite Telus' opposition
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trade-marks Opposition Board decision
Evidence_Assessment: Board reviewed evidence including memorability and market context of the marks
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; Orange's trademark registration upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On Telus to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Board found Telus' argument unconvincing based on differences in marks and context
Legal_Rule: Confusion assessed based on first impression and imperfect recollection, considering distinctiveness, use, resemblance, and market state
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Likelihood of consumer confusion between 'Future's Bright' and 'Future is Friendly'
Outcome_on_Merits: No reasonable likelihood of confusion found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Distinctiveness of marks, market usage, consumer perception, memorability
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, principles of trademark confusion
Defendant_Response: Orange defended registration, emphasizing differences in branding and market presence
Evidence_Type: Comparative trademark analysis, market context, consumer perception arguments
Remedy_Requested: Cancellation or refusal of Orange's trademark registration
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Trade-marks Act relating to confusion and registrability
Authority: Trade-marks Opposition Board, appellate review body

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the statement of claim discloses a reasonable cause of action for patent infringement and whether the order for particulars was justified
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from motions to strike and for particulars
Evidence_Assessment: Amended statement of claim lacked specific facts showing personal involvement of Andre Teasdale in infringing activities
Decision_Outcome: Appeal partially allowed: claim against Andre Teasdale dismissed; order for particulars on other licensees overturned; order for particulars on inducement upheld
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must demonstrate reasonable cause of action with sufficient factual basis
Credibility_Factor: Lack of specific allegations indicating knowing, wilful participation by Andre Teasdale
Legal_Rule: Personal liability for corporate torts requires knowing, wilful participation; statement of claim must disclose reasonable cause of action
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness of cause of action under procedural rules
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement by corporate defendants and individual liability of Andre Teasdale as President
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim against Andre Teasdale failed due to insufficient personal involvement alleged
Key_Evidence_Considered: Amended statement of claim, role of Andre Teasdale as President, lack of direct involvement in infringement
Legal_Framework: Canadian Federal Court civil procedure, patent law
Defendant_Response: Motion to strike claim against Andre Teasdale and challenge relevance of requested particulars
Evidence_Type: Pleading documents, allegations in statement of claim
Remedy_Requested: Particulars on inducement and licensing activities
Outcome: Claim against Andre Teasdale struck; partial success on appeal regarding particulars
Legal_Provision: Rule 419(1)(a) of the Federal Courts Rules
Authority: Senior Prothonotary's decision under review on appeal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with a Recognizance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility issues, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board's decision can be overturned if findings unsupported or legal analysis incorrect
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable assessment of danger and alternatives to detention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Past gang ties, lack of credible bondspersons, rehabilitation efforts
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged detention as unjustified and disproportionate
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility concerns, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Decision subject to judicial review if findings lack evidentiary support or legal error
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consideration of current dangerousness and alternatives
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: History of interactions with law enforcement, rehabilitation evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued he was not a current risk and suitable for release
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and release on bail
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility and detention based on criminality
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Adequacy of consideration of evidence and alternatives
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence considered but not sufficiently weighed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention maintained due to perceived danger
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under Federal Court rules
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of gang association and related charges
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between past conduct and potential future risk
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Board record, police reports, applicant testimony
Crimes.Outcome: Court found decision unreasonable, ordered new hearing
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Perceived ongoing danger and flight risk
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to adequately assess current risk and alternatives

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Insufficient analysis of current danger and alternatives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention extended based on public safety concerns
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged drug trafficking and gang-related activity
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Prior involvement in organized crime and drug offenses
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Connection between past criminal behavior and potential reoffending
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Police records, Board proceedings, applicant statements
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to meaningfully consider rehabilitation and less restrictive options

Legal_Issue: Whether Sandoz's claims of patent invalidity based on broader claims and bad faith can be struck out
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; Prothonotary's Order set aside
Legal_Rule: The test for striking out pleadings is whether it is 'plain and obvious' that the allegations are legally untenable
Grounds_for_Claim: Patent invalidity due to broader claims than disclosed and bad faith in omitting prior art
Outcome_on_Merits: Sandoz's claims of invalidity not struck out; preserved for further proceedings
Legal_Framework: Federal Court jurisdiction over patent matters
Remedy_Requested: Striking out of Sandoz's invalidity claims (by Bayer); appeal to reinstate claims (by Sandoz)
Outcome: Sandoz retains its claims and costs

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to analyze subjective fear of persecution before assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted by tribunal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged threats from FARC in Ecuador
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Subjective fear must precede state protection analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Credibility and plausibility of applicant's fear
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Subjective fear analysis required prior to state protection evaluation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to assess subjective fear before determining state protection availability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Lack of credibility analysis regarding fear of persecution
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish subjective fear
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Threats from FARC not assessed for credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subjective fear must be evaluated before state protection
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative tribunal decision under review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in the U.S. and illegal entry into Canada
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Ecuador, overstayed U.S. visa, entered Canada illegally
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status in both U.S. and Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential failure to disclose prior unlawful stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Sequence of refugee claim analysis under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged FARC threats and flight path
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credibility assessment of applicant's fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not performed by Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness due to omitted fear analysis
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to seek asylum in the United States
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to pursue available asylum protection in a safe third country
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Safe Third Country Agreement between Canada and the U.S.
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in U.S. illegally after fleeing Ecuador, did not apply for asylum there
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential omission or justification of failure to claim asylum in U.S.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to assess subjective fear before evaluating state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of state protection analysis sequence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No analysis of credibility or plausibility of fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mandatory sequence: subjective fear before state protection

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer erred in dismissing the claim due to lack of evidence and misunderstanding of risks under s. 96 and s. 97
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration by a different Officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to properly assess credibility of new evidence and medical reports
Legal_Provision: s. 97 IRPA (Person in need of protection)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution and risk to life due to land dispute and family violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing threats despite cessation of land dispute pursuit
Crimes.Application_Error: Dismissal of new evidence without valid reasoning
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Connection to Convention grounds or risk under s. 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal vendetta vs. broader persecution analysis

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats linked to familial land dispute
Crimes.Victim_Status: Applicant facing credible threats from relative
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator is a Kenyan police officer; history of violence and murders linked to dispute
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of violent acts including murder attributed to perpetrator
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing and credible risk of harm or death
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized threat due to familial conflict with potential state actor involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to justify dismissal of credible evidence

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Assault arising from familial land dispute
Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual subjected to physical violence and threats
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Involvement of state actor (police officer cousin); ongoing nature of threats
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of violent behavior including prior assaults
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized, non-state actor with state connections
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Adequate evidence presented but not properly analyzed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer dismissed evidence without justification

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided but dismissed without proper analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supportive of PTSD and ongoing danger
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to engage with medical and documentary evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide necessaries of life
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer properly assessed new evidence and state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to consider new evidence on threats and murders
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show risk, but officer must fairly assess evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Medical report supporting PTSD diagnosis ignored
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Requirement of well-founded fear or risk under IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution and risk to life due to land dispute
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected initially, later quashed on judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee protection under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection claimed but inadequately analyzed

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Land ownership dispute involving family member who is a police officer
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer erred in rejecting new evidence and assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to assess credibility of new threat evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution and risk to life due to personal conflict with state-linked actor
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Involvement of police officer cousin and pattern of violence
Crimes.Application_Error: Improper dismissal of evidence and flawed legal application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for facts, correctness for legal interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Nexus to Convention grounds or risk under s. 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal vendetta versus systemic risk analysis

Violation_Type: Failure to establish proper nexus to a Convention ground
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 96, 97
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Sri Lankan Tamil individual fled persecution; associated with passengers aboard MV Sun Sea; claimed fear of persecution based on ethnicity and association
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review for mixed questions of law and fact
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's jurisdiction under IRPA subsection 72(1) for judicial review
Evidence_Used: RPD findings on Tamil ethnicity and association with MV Sun Sea passengers
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Deficiencies in linking association with MV Sun Sea to Convention grounds
Decision_Outcome: RPD granted refugee status based on nexus to Convention ground of race (Tamil ethnicity)
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; RPD decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD's refugee status determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Nexus between fear of persecution and a Convention ground
Decision_Rationale: RPD's finding of nexus based on race (Tamil ethnicity) was reasonable; deficiencies in other factors did not undermine the overall decision

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on risk as a Sikh and Akali Dal member, family ties in Canada, and best interests of a child
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident applicant under H&C consideration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA application rejected; judicial review filed
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Sikhs in India
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of disproportionate hardship; unreliable corroborative evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not sufficiently credible or substantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or undeserved hardship demonstrated; country conditions improved for Sikhs; insufficient Canadian ties to outweigh immigration compliance
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with deportation order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa overstay and multiple failed H&C applications, including post-removal risk assessment
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to deportation order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant (failed to depart after deportation order)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PRRA officer's rejection of H&C application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration and removal decisions
Evidence_Used: Family and community ties in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting risk or exceptional hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims regarding political affiliation and risk not adequately supported
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected; deportation order upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certified question and quashing of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: PRRA officer reasonably concluded no disproportionate hardship; country conditions do not support well-founded fear; insufficient grounds to interfere
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision to deny the Applicant's work permit application reasonable based on the evidence provided?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application filed under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer misapprehended facts: ignored submitted work experience documents, overemphasized economic incentives without cost-of-living analysis, incorrectly assumed language barriers would prevent job performance
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to misapprehension of facts
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant provided relevant documentation and explanations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Judicial review can be sought if decision is unreasonable or made without considering material evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misapprehension of key facts and failure to consider submitted evidence
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Court found in favor of applicant
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside; case referred for re-evaluation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision to deny the Applicant's work permit application reasonable based on the evidence provided?
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside; case referred for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer unjustly concluded about English language ability without evidence
Evidence_Type: Explanations regarding qualifications and ties to India
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived lack of qualifications and ties to India
Crimes.Application_Error: Ignored submitted work experience, overemphasized economic incentives, no cost-of-living comparison, incorrect assumption on language ability
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision based on full evidentiary record
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement to consider all material evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Qualifications and ties to home country
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to factual misapprehension
Crimes.Document_Fraud: None found; issue was officer error, not applicant fraud

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of forced marriage; RPD and RAD found lack of credibility; international flight alternative existed
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fear of forced marriage deemed not credible by RPD and RAD
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, supporting documents (if any), credibility assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish credibility of fear of forced marriage
Credibility_Assessment: RPD and RAD found applicant not credible; RAD applied reasonableness standard
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Decision_Rationale: Credibility concerns and availability of safe country alternative
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Risk of persecution in Pakistan due to religious activities
Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer err in rejecting the applicant's evidence and refusing an oral hearing?
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence assigned low probative value due to lack of specific details or objective proof
Legal_Provision: PRRA assessment standards, Refugee Protection Division determinations
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on religious activities
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of new credible evidence warranting an oral hearing
Application_Error: Alleged error in rejecting evidence and denying oral hearing
Assessment_Standard: Fair assessment of new evidence, credibility and relevance
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, standard of review for PRRA decisions
Application_Factor: Previous rejection by Refugee Protection Division

Violation_Type: Failure to consider compelling reasons exception
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed past persecution in Sri Lanka, including torture; Board found changed circumstances but did not assess s. 108(4); applicant's testimony was corroborated and not discredited
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address statutory requirement under s. 108(4) despite evidence of past persecution
Evidence_Used: Testimony on past torture, corroborated by evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not analyze whether compelling reasons arising from past persecution warranted exemption under s. 108(4)
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's testimony was credible and not discredited
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected claim based on changed circumstances
Relief_Sought: Recognition of refugee protection based on compelling reasons from past persecution
Legal_Standard_Applied: s. 108(4) of IRPA – compelling reasons due to past persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board erred by not considering s. 108(4) after finding changed circumstances and accepting evidence of past persecution
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Refugee Protection Division

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide acceptable identity documentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case remanded for re-evaluation
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Federal Courts Act
Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision, remanded to new Board member
Credibility: Minor inconsistencies in testimony deemed significant

Legal_Issue: Rejection based on minor testimonial inconsistencies
Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case referred back for reassessment
Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies, translation issues, but substantial corroborating details
Basis_of_Claim: Lack of Somali identity documents, use of fraudulent passports
Legal_Standard: Reasonable justification for lack of documentation

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board member's decision violated the applicant's rights under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible risk of persecution due to no LTTE association and improved conditions in Sri Lanka
Evidence_Type: Personal claim of ethnicity and perceived LTTE ties, country condition reports
Legal_Provision: Sections related to refugee protection and eligibility under IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Ethnicity (Tamil) and perceived association with LTTE
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No credible link to LTTE and post-conflict improvements in Sri Lanka
Application_Factor: Persecution risk based on identity and political opinion
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, status not granted

Application_Facts: Mr. Nagulesan submitted corroborative evidence after the hearing but before the decision was made; the RPD did not consider it despite proper submission procedures being followed.
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider additional evidence submitted post-hearing, breaching duty of fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant corroborative evidence impacted credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due in part to exclusion of new evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to lack of credibility and insufficient evidence
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review; RPD decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim by a different panel
Decision_Rationale: The RPD had a duty to consider properly submitted post-hearing evidence under Rule 37; failure to do so rendered the process unfair

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Convention refugee status based on past persecution in Chile; Tribunal accepted credible evidence of past persecution but dismissed claim due to changed country conditions without addressing s. 2(3)
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to consider s. 2(3) despite evidence of past persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess compelling reasons arising from past persecution under s. 2(3)
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant's evidence was found credible
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed based on changed country conditions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act regarding continued refugee status despite changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Tribunal erred in law by not considering s. 2(3) which requires assessment of compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration status requirements
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with immigration status and removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) provisions regarding stay conditions and removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to provide credible evidence of risk upon return to Kenya; claims were assessed multiple times with consistent findings of no significant risk
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to a removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed authorized period and failed to meet immigration status requirements
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not explicitly found, but lack of credible evidence undermines claim legitimacy
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Repeated filing of stay motions without new or compelling evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Canadian immigration authorities and federal court over removal matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Prior decisions, country condition reports on Kenya, applicant’s submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, specific, and corroborated evidence of personal risk in Kenya
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed not credible due to lack of supporting documentation and consistency
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay of removal dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending further review or relief
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test: (1) serious issue to be tried, (2) irreparable harm, (3) balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet any branch of the tri-partite test; balance of convenience favors enforcement of removal due to statutory obligations
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board and Federal Court

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) – cessation of temporary resident status upon expiry of authorized stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration; filed multiple stay applications without new evidence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident, now illegally present
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and failed to depart upon expiry
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No direct finding, but repetitive litigation tactics suggest procedural abuse
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Abuse of process through repeated stay motions lacking merit
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration enforcement and judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa records, country condition reports, history of previous applications
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentary support for claimed risks; general country reports indicate stability in Kenya
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to unsubstantiated claims and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay of removal dismissed
Crimes.Outcome: Removal from Canada ordered and will proceed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal to allow further consideration of claim
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test for interim relief: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious issue established; no irreparable harm shown; balance of convenience favors timely enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency and Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board's decision on delay in filing refugee claim
Outcome: Board's decision upheld; judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations for delay found unpersuasive; legal background and access to advice undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Psychological evidence, applicant's statements, legal documentation
Evidence_Ignored: None identified – psychological evidence considered but not supportive
Legal_Standard: Delay may indicate lack of subjective fear but not decisive unless circumstances warrant
Application_Factor: Delay in filing, credibility, access to legal advice

Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain immigration benefits
Legal_Issue: Did the CRDD err in rejecting the applicant's claim based on credibility and fabrication of evidence?
Outcome: The CRDD's decision is set aside due to reviewable error, and the case is remanded for reconsideration.
Credibility_Assessment: The CRDD doubted the applicant's credibility without sufficient evidence and misinterpreted supporting documents.
Application_Error: Basing credibility solely on lack of documentation
Assessment_Standard: The CRDD must provide clear reasons for rejecting evidence and cannot base credibility solely on lack of documentation.
Legal_Standard: The CRDD must evaluate evidence fairly, considering all documentation and testimony.
Standard_of_Review: Judicial review analyzed the CRDD's decision, applying legal standards for evaluating evidence and credibility.
Document_Fraud: Fabrication of evidence regarding police actions

Legal_Issue: Was the CRDD's decision to reject the applicant's claim based on credible evidence and proper evaluation of facts?
Outcome: The CRDD's decision was flawed due to disregard for material evidence. The case is referred back for redetermination.
Credibility_Assessment: The CRDD doubted the applicant's credibility due to perceived inconsistencies in his evidence.
Basis_of_Claim: Family harassment due to brother's involvement in Sikh separatism
Application_Error: Dismissal of key testimonies and reports
Assessment_Standard: The CRDD must evaluate evidence fairly, considering all documentation and testimony. Inconsistencies must be supported by evidence.
Evidence_Ignored: Expert testimony on plausibility of abuse
Legal_Standard: The CRDD must evaluate evidence fairly, considering all documentation and testimony.
Standard_of_Review: Judicial review analyzed CRDD's credibility assessment and evidence evaluation, finding errors in dismissing key testimonies and reports.
Document_Fraud: Alleged fabrication of police actions and medical report

Prior_Criminality: Applicant’s past behavior indicated potential recidivism
Risk_Assessment: deportation risk would be assessed later
Evidence_Sufficiency: updated psychological assessments were not considered due to late submission
Legal_Provision: subsection 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
subsection 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Issue: adequate consideration of rehabilitation and home country conditions
Evidence_Assessment: rehabilitation efforts considered but deemed insufficient
Legal_Rule: subsection 44(2) IRPA

Risk_Nexus: deportation risk to be assessed later
Basis_for_Decision: past criminal behavior outweighs humanitarian factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Taking a motor vehicle without consent
Evidence_Sufficiency: updated psychological assessments not considered due to procedural issues
Legal_Provision: subsection 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Application_Facts: criminal convictions led to admissibility report
Procedural_Issue: late submission of updated psychological assessment

Dispute_Type: admissibility referral based on criminal record
Legal_Issue: consideration of rehabilitation and country conditions
Evidence_Assessment: rehabilitation noted, updated psychological assessment late
Legal_Rule: subsection 44(2) allows referral if report is well-founded
Defendant_Response: provided evidence of rehabilitation and risks

Risk_Assessment: risk assessment to occur before deportation
Evidence_Sufficiency: updated psychological assessment did not materially change conclusions
Legal_Provision: subsection 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Issue: consideration of rehabilitation and country conditions
Evidence_Assessment: updated psychological assessment not considered due to late submission
Legal_Rule: Delegate may refer if report is well-founded

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to comply with a probation order

Legal_Provision: subsection 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime under $5000
Legal_Issue: consideration of rehabilitation and country risks
Evidence_Assessment: some rehabilitation referenced, updated assessment not considered
Legal_Rule: Delegate may refer if opinion is well-founded

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime over $5000
Dispute_Type: admissibility referral based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: adequacy of factor consideration by Delegate
Evidence_Assessment: omitted evidence did not materially affect outcome
Legal_Rule: Delegate must act reasonably
Defendant_Response: provided evidence of rehabilitation and risks

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed to have attached a report on St. Vincent's medical care for deaf children; immigration officer stated the report was not received; application refused due to lack of corroborative evidence despite applicant mentioning the attachment.
Claimant_Status: Applicant under humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Procedural_Issue: Failure to inform applicant that report was missing and to provide opportunity to resubmit
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Missing report on medical care for deaf children in St. Vincent
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application
Outcome: Judicial review granted, original decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of case to another immigration officer for reassessment
Decision_Rationale: Officer breached procedural fairness by not notifying applicant of missing document and denying opportunity to provide it
